Articles.Content:
My copy of KSP is unplayable due to the fact that the different colors within images do not match up exactly. I've included a screenshot.

This is the Steam version. I'm running off a clean install.

I'm running Windows 10 (64-bit) with the NVIDIA GeForce GT 620 card.

http://postimg.org/image/gydk7jxxv/

Hi bjohn13, wow, that looks like a stereo image or anaglyph, KSP doesn't have an anaglyph mode, nor does the unity3D engine as far as I can tell, not without using a plugin anyway.

Please put your KSP.log, output_log.txt (it's in KSP_Data), dxdiag report and list of running processes on dropbox or a similar file sharing site, and I'll see if I can figure this out.

Edited August 22, 2015 by sal_vager

First, welcome to the forums !

Then, seeing your screenshot, I wouldn't call the game unplayable, put on some ol' Red 'n' Blue 3D glasses and you will see what is your problem (just turn off 3D anaglyph somewhere in the settings).

Actually, I don't remember ever seeing a 3D option in the KSP settings, it may be an issue from your PC's graphical settings.

I'm still wondering if I was supposed to answer this seriously or not...

EDIT: ninja'd

Edited August 22, 2015 by Gaarst

I'm told that this is a graphics driver setting, though I have never seen it in the Linux Nvidia driver.

Take a look here, don't forget your cool 80's red/green shades!

Edit:

It just occurred to me that you're aware of this mode, but want the effect to be correct so your anaglyph glasses work.

If this is the case I don't think I can help you, KSP doesn't have any support for anaglyphs.

There are controls to correct this but you may be better off just turning it off.

Edited August 22, 2015 by sal_vager

Thank you so much for your quick replies.

There was enough information here to help me solve my issue. I figured it was a simple setting somewhere.

I had no idea that my graphics card had a "stereoscopic 3D" setting. That little tidbit of information led me to the google machine to figure out how to disable it.

From Control Panel, I opened my NVIDIA Control Panel. From the left side task tree, I selected "Stereoscopic 3D>Set up stereoscopic 3D". From there, I unchecked the "Enable stereoscopic 3D" box. Problem solved.

It's weird that I've been running this card for over a year, and I've played dozens of games on it. This is the first time this has come up. Yeah. This is one of those things I never want enabled. Strange that it would come enabled as the default setting. That whole concept of 3D vision in movies has never worked for me due to an eye condition that I have.

I appreciate all of your help.

Bryan
